title: Basic Design Of The Plots
text: package provides set color palettes widely used. different packages used different tools, including: viridis viridis package brewer.pal.info RColorBrewer package ggsci_db ggsci package redmonder.pal.info Redmonder package metacartocolors rcartocolor package nord_palettes nord package ocean palettes syspals pals package colorschemes dichromat package custom palettes including jcolors package palettes provided SCP package. addition, SCP package also provides set color palettes widely used single-cell analysis, including: discrete colour palettes DiscretePalette Seurat package scales::hue_pal used Seurat See also following documentation details: available color palettes show_palettes palette_this

what: Basic implementation of the plotting functions
title: Basic Design Of The Plots
text: plotting functions plotthis implemented following structure:
code: SomePlot <- function(     data,     # The column to split the data and plot     # When `facet` is TRUE, the columns specified here will be used to facet the plot     # When `facet` is FALSE, the columns specified here will be used to split the data     #   and generate multiple plots and combine them into one     # If multiple columns are specified     #   When `facet` is TRUE, up to 2 columns are allowed. If one column,     #     `ggplot2::facet_wrap` is used, the number of rows and columns is determined     #     by `nrow` and `ncol`     #   When `facet` is FALSE, a warning will be issued and the columns will be     #     concatenated into one column, using `split_by_sep` as the separator     split_by, split_by_sep,     # Columns to group the data for plotting     # For those plotting functions that do not support multiple groups,     # They will be concatenated into one column, using `group_by_sep` as the separator     group_by, group_by_sep,     # Whether to facet the plot, or split the data and combine the plots     facet, facet_scales,     # Controls for theming     theme, theme_args, palette, palcolor, keep_empty, x_text_angle, aspect.ratio,     legend.position, legend.direction, alpha, title, subtitle, xlab, ylab,     # The number of rows and columns when `facet_wrap` is used or     # when `facet` is FALSE, the number of rows and columns to combine the plots     # For facet_wrap, dir = 'v' will be used when byrow = FALSE     combine, nrow, ncol, byrow     # Whether to guess the width and height of the plot in pixels     # list(plot, width, height) will be returned instead of the plot if TRUE     seed,     ... ) {      # Argument validation      # Data preparation     #   Data will be transformed based on the arguments     #   and split into a list of data frames by split_by      # Plot for each split data frame     plots <- lapply(split_data, function(df) {         # Calling atomic plotting functions to generate the plot         #   These functions do not need to handle split         #   All data passed to these functions should feed to the plot         SomePlotAtomic(df, ...)     })      # Combine the plots     #     patch_work::wrap_plots(plots, nrow, ncol, byrow) }

title: Basic Design Of The Plots
text: Unlike plotting packages, plotthis provides unified interface splitting faceting. plots created ggplot2 behind scenes, plotthis “facet-aware”. plotting functions plotthis support splitting faceting. split_by argument used split data generate multiple plots, data split_by columns used split data generate multiple plots, combined one plot. sub-plots independent , scales guides. addition, split_by_sep argument used concatenate columns specified split_by one column, using specified separator. palettes/palcolors can different sub-plot using palette/palcolor argument. faceting, facet_scales argument used control scales facets. facet_wrap function used facet_by one column; otherwise, facet_grid function used facet_by two columns. plots support faceting (built directly based ggplot2), split_by good choice split data generate multiple plots.

title: Basic Design Of The Plots
text: arguments plotting functions named consistent way. _ used separate words argument names, favor ., unless argument passed ggplot2 function (e.g. theme). _ used separate words argument names make argument names readable less confusing . function names, work method call. argument names lowercased.

title: Basic Design Of The Plots
text: plots created plotthis come height width attribute. experimental feature used guess size plot inches. Note actual size plot. just guess based elements plot. can use values set fig.width fig.height arguments chunk options R Markdown options(repr.plot.width = ...) options(repr.plot.height = ...) Jupyter notebooks. can also use save plot file guessed size. example:
code: p <- SomePlot(x, ...) png("plot.png", width = attr(p, "width") * 100, height = attr(p, "height") * 100, res = 100) print(p) dev.off()

what: Tracing the ggplot calls for debugging
title: Basic Design Of The Plots
text: plot created ggplot2 behind scenes, plotthis relies gglogger package trace ggplot2 calls. gglogger package used log ggplot2 calls arguments passed ggplot2 functions. useful debugging understanding plot created.
code: options(plotthis.gglogger.enabled = TRUE)  p <- BarPlot(data = iris, x = "Species") p$logs  # ggplot2::ggplot(data, aes(x = !!sym(x), y = !!sym(y), fill = !!sym(x))) + #   geom_col(alpha = alpha, width = width) + #   scale_fill_manual(name = x, values = colors, guide = guide) + #   labs(title = title, subtitle = subtitle, x = xlab %||% x, y = ylab %||% #     y) + #   scale_x_discrete(drop = !keep_empty, expand = expand$x) + #   scale_y_continuous(expand = expand$y) + #   do.call(theme, theme_args) + #   ggplot2::theme(aspect.ratio = aspect.ratio, legend.position = legend.position, #     legend.direction = legend.direction, panel.grid.major = element_line(colour = "grey80", #         linetype = 2), axis.text.x = element_text(angle = x_text_angle, #         hjust = just$h, vjust = just$v)) + #   coord_cartesian(ylim = c(y_min, y_max))

title: Basic Design Of The Plots
text: extra data needed plotting, plotthis usually provides argument receive . can prepare data attached attribute main data frame, pass @extra argument. function can access extra data attr(data, "extra"). example:
code: data <- gsea_result attr(data, "gene_ranks") <- gene_ranks attr(data, "gene_sets") <- gene_sets GSEAPlot(data)  # Equivalent to GSEAPlot(data, gene_ranks = gene_ranks, gene_sets = gene_sets)

what: High-Level Plotting Built Upon ggplot2 and Other Plotting Packages
title: High-Level Plotting Built Upon ggplot2 and Other Plotting Packages
text: plotthis R package built upon ggplot2 plotting packages. provides high-level APIs wide range options create stunning, publication-quality plots effortlessly.

title: High-Level Plotting Built Upon ggplot2 and Other Plotting Packages
text: can also install package using conda:
code: install.packages("plotthis") # or to install the latest version: remotes::install_github("pwwang/plotthis") devtools::install_github("pwwang/plotthis") $ conda install pwwang::r-plotthis

title: Area plot — AreaPlot
code: AreaPlot(   data,   x,   y = NULL,   x_sep = "_",   split_by = NULL,   split_by_sep = "_",   group_by = NULL,   group_by_sep = "_",   group_name = NULL,   scale_y = FALSE,   theme = "theme_this",   theme_args = list(),   palette = "Paired",   palcolor = NULL,   alpha = 1,   facet_by = NULL,   facet_scales = "fixed",   facet_ncol = NULL,   facet_nrow = NULL,   facet_byrow = TRUE,   x_text_angle = 0,   aspect.ratio = 1,   legend.position = waiver(),   legend.direction = "vertical",   title = NULL,   subtitle = NULL,   xlab = NULL,   ylab = NULL,   keep_empty = FALSE,   seed = 8525,   combine = TRUE,   nrow = NULL,   ncol = NULL,   byrow = TRUE,   axes = NULL,   axis_titles = axes,   guides = NULL,   design = NULL,   ... )

title: Area plot — AreaPlot
text: data data frame. x character string specifying column name data frame plot x-axis. y character string specifying column name data frame plot y-axis. x_sep character string concatenate columns x, multiple columns provided. split_by column(s) split data plot separately. split_by_sep separator multiple split_by columns. See split_by group_by Columns group data plotting plotting functions support multiple groups, concatenated one column, using group_by_sep separator group_by_sep separator multiple group_by columns. See group_by group_name character string name legend fill. scale_y logical value scale y-axis total number x-axis group. theme character string theme class (.e. ggplot2::theme_classic) specifying theme use. Default "theme_this". theme_args list arguments pass theme function. palette character string specifying palette use. named list vector can used specify palettes different split_by values. palcolor character string specifying color use palette. named list can used specify colors different split_by values. values missing, values palette used (palcolor NULL values). alpha numeric value specifying transparency plot. facet_by character string specifying column name data frame facet plot. Otherwise, data split split_by generate multiple plots combine one using patchwork::wrap_plots facet_scales Whether scale axes facets. Default "fixed" options "free", "free_x", "free_y". See ggplot2::facet_wrap facet_ncol numeric value specifying number columns facet. facet_by single column facet_wrap used. facet_nrow numeric value specifying number rows facet. facet_by single column facet_wrap used. facet_byrow logical value indicating whether fill plots row. Default TRUE. x_text_angle numeric value specifying angle x-axis text. aspect.ratio numeric value specifying aspect ratio plot. legend.position character string specifying position legend. waiver(), single groups, legend "none", otherwise "right". legend.direction character string specifying direction legend. title character string specifying title plot. function can used generate title based default title. useful split_by used title needs dynamic. subtitle character string specifying subtitle plot. xlab character string specifying x-axis label. ylab character string specifying y-axis label. keep_empty logical value indicating whether keep empty groups. FALSE, empty groups removed. seed random seed use. Default 8525. combine Whether combine plots one facet FALSE. Default TRUE. nrow numeric value specifying number rows facet. ncol numeric value specifying number columns facet. byrow logical value indicating whether fill plots row. axes string specifying axes treated. Passed patchwork::wrap_plots(). relevant split_by used combine TRUE. Options : 'keep' retain axes individual plots. 'collect' remove duplicated axes placed run rows columns layout. 'collect_x' 'collect_y' remove duplicated x-axes columns duplicated y-axes rows respectively. axis_titles string specifying axis titltes treated. Passed patchwork::wrap_plots(). relevant split_by used combine TRUE. Options : 'keep' retain axis titles individual plots. 'collect' remove duplicated titles one direction merge titles opposite direction. 'collect_x' 'collect_y' control x-axis titles y-axis titles respectively. guides string specifying guides treated layout. Passed patchwork::wrap_plots(). relevant split_by used combine TRUE. Options : 'collect' collect guides given nesting level, removing duplicates. 'keep' stop collection level let guides placed alongside plot. 'auto' allow guides collected upper level tries, place alongside plot . design Specification location areas layout, passed patchwork::wrap_plots(). relevant split_by used combine TRUE. specified, nrow, ncol, byrow ignored. See patchwork::wrap_plots() details. ... Additional arguments.

Either "box" "violin". in_form character string specify input data type. Either "long" "wide". split_by column(s) split data plot separately. split_by_sep separator multiple split_by columns. See split_by symnum_args list arguments pass function symnum symbolic number coding p-values. example, symnum_args <- list(cutpoints = c(0, 0.0001, 0.001, 0.01, 0.05, Inf), symbols = c("****", "***", "**", "*", "ns")). words, use following convention symbols indicating statistical significance: ns: p > 0.05 *: p <= 0.05 **: p <= 0.01 ***: p <= 0.001 ****: p <= 0.0001 sort_x character string specify sorting x-axis, chosen "none", "mean_asc", "mean_desc", "mean", "median_asc", "median_desc", "median". none means sorting (-). mean_asc sorts x-axis ascending mean y-values. mean_desc sorts x-axis descending mean y-values. mean alias mean_asc. median_asc sorts x-axis ascending median y-values. median_desc sorts x-axis descending median y-values. median alias median_asc. flip logical value flip plot. keep_empty logical value indicating whether keep empty groups. FALSE, empty groups removed. group_by Columns group data plotting plotting functions support multiple groups, concatenated one column, using group_by_sep separator group_by_sep separator multiple group_by columns. See group_by group_name character string name legend dodge. paired_by character string column name identifying paired observations paired tests. x_text_angle numeric value specifying angle x-axis text. step_increase numeric value specify step increase fraction total height every additional comparison significance labels. fill_mode character string specify fill mode. Either "dodge", "x", "mean", "median". fill_reverse logical value reverse fill colors gradient fill (mean/median). theme character string theme class (.e. ggplot2::theme_classic) specifying theme use. Default "theme_this". theme_args list arguments pass theme function. palette character string specifying palette use. named list vector can used specify palettes different split_by values. palcolor character string specifying color use palette. named list can used specify colors different split_by values. values missing, values palette used (palcolor NULL values). alpha numeric value specifying transparency plot. aspect.ratio numeric value specifying aspect ratio plot. legend.position character string specifying position legend. waiver(), single groups, legend "none", otherwise "right". legend.direction character string specifying direction legend. add_point logical value add (jitter) points plot. pt_color character string specify color points. pt_size numeric value specify size points. pt_alpha numeric value specify transparency points. jitter_width numeric value specify width jitter. Defaults 0.5, paired_by provided, set 0. jitter_height numeric value specify height jitter. stack logical value whether stack facetted plot 'facet_by'. y_max numeric value character string specify maximum value y-axis. can also use quantile notation like "q95" specify 95th percentile. comparisons set numeric y_max provided, used set y-axis limit, including significance labels. y_min numeric value character string specify minimum value y-axis. can also use quantile notation like "q5" specify 5th percentile. add_box logical value add box plot plot. box_color character string specify color box plot. box_width numeric value specify width box plot. box_ptsize numeric value specify size box plot points middle. add_trend logical value add trend line plot. trend_color character string specify color trend line. work group_by specified, trend line colored group_by variable.#' trend_linewidth numeric value specify width trend line. trend_ptsize numeric value specify size trend line points. add_stat character string add statistical test plot. stat_name character string specify name stat legend. stat_color character string specify color statistical test. stat_size numeric value specify size statistical test. stat_stroke numeric value specify stroke statistical test. stat_shape numeric value specify shape statistical test. add_bg logical value add background plot. bg_palette character string specify palette background. bg_palcolor character vector specify colors background. bg_alpha numeric value specify transparency background. add_line character string add line plot. line_color character string specify color line. line_width numeric value specify size line. line_type numeric value specify type line. highlight vector character strings highlight points. subset row names data. TRUE, highlight points. highlight_color character string specify color highlighted points. highlight_size numeric value specify size highlighted points. highlight_alpha numeric value specify transparency highlighted points. comparisons logical value list vectors perform pairwise comparisons. TRUE, perform pairwise comparisons pairs. ref_group character string specify reference group comparisons. pairwise_method character string specify pairwise comparison method. multiplegroup_comparisons logical value perform multiple group comparisons. multiple_method character string specify multiple group comparison method. sig_label character string specify label significance test. multiple group comparisons (multiplegroup_comparisons = TRUE), must either "p.format" "p.signif". pairwise comparisons, can : column containing label (e.g.: label = "p" label = "p.adj"), p p-value. possible values "p.signif", "p.adj.signif", "p.format", "p.adj.format". expression can formatted glue() package. example, specifying label = "Wilcoxon, p = {p}", expression {p} replaced value. combination plotmath expressions glue expressions. may want statistical parameter italic; example: label = "Wilcoxon, p= {p}" See https://rpkgs.datanovia.com/ggpubr/reference/geom_pwc.html details. sig_labelsize numeric value specify size significance test label. hide_ns logical value hide non-significant comparisons. facet_by character string specifying column name data frame facet plot. code: # \donttest{ set.seed(8525)  matrix_data <- matrix(rnorm(60), nrow = 6, ncol = 10) rownames(matrix_data) <- paste0("R", 1:6) colnames(matrix_data) <- paste0("C", 1:10) if (requireNamespace("cluster", quietly = TRUE)) {     Heatmap(matrix_data) }  if (requireNamespace("cluster", quietly = TRUE)) {     # use a different color palette     # change the main legend title     # show row names (legend will be hidden)     # show column names     # change the row name annotation name and side     # change the column name annotation name     Heatmap(matrix_data, palette = "viridis", values_by = "z-score",        show_row_names = TRUE, show_column_names = TRUE,        rows_name = "Features", row_names_side = "left",        columns_name = "Samples") }  if (requireNamespace("cluster", quietly = TRUE)) {     # flip the heatmap     Heatmap(matrix_data, palette = "viridis", values_by = "z-score",        show_row_names = TRUE, show_column_names = TRUE,        rows_name = "Features", row_names_side = "left",        columns_name = "Samples", flip = TRUE) }  if (requireNamespace("cluster", quietly = TRUE)) {     # add annotations to the heatmap     rows_data <- data.frame(        rows = paste0("R", 1:6),        group = sample(c("X", "Y", "Z"), 6, replace = TRUE)     )     Heatmap(matrix_data, rows_data = rows_data,         row_annotation = list(Group = "group"),         row_annotation_type = list(Group = "simple"),         row_annotation_palette = list(Group = "Spectral")     ) } #> Warning: [Heatmap] Assuming 'row_annotation_agg["Group"] = dplyr::first' for the simple annotation  if (requireNamespace("cluster", quietly = TRUE)) {     Heatmap(matrix_data, rows_data = rows_data,         rows_split_by = "group"     ) }  if (requireNamespace("cluster", quietly = TRUE)) {     # add labels to the heatmap     Heatmap(matrix_data, rows_data = rows_data,         rows_split_by = "group", cell_type = "label",         label = function(x) ifelse(             x > 0, scales::number(x, accuracy = 0.01), NA         )     ) }  if (requireNamespace("cluster", quietly = TRUE)) {     # add labels based on an external data     pvalues <- matrix(runif(60, 0, 0.5), nrow = 6, ncol = 10)     Heatmap(matrix_data, rows_data = rows_data,         rows_split_by = "group", cell_type = "label",         label = function(x, i, j) {             pv <- ComplexHeatmap::pindex(pvalues, i, j)             ifelse(pv < 0.01, "***",             ifelse(pv < 0.05, "**",             ifelse(pv < 0.1, "*", NA)))         }     ) }  if (requireNamespace("cluster", quietly = TRUE)) {     # quickly simulate a GO board     go <- matrix(sample(c(0, 1, NA), 81, replace = TRUE), ncol = 9)      Heatmap(         go,         # Do not cluster rows and columns and hide the annotations         cluster_rows = FALSE, cluster_columns = FALSE,         row_name_annotation = FALSE, column_name_annotation = FALSE,         show_row_names = FALSE, show_column_names = FALSE,         # Set the legend items         values_by = "Players", legend_discrete = TRUE,         legend_items = c("Player 1" = 0, "Player 2" = 1),         # Set the pawns         cell_type = "dot", dot_size = function(x) ifelse(is.na(x), 0, 10),         dot_size_name = NULL,  # hide the dot size legend         palcolor = c("white", "black"),         # Set the board         add_reticle = TRUE,         # Set the size of the board         width = ggplot2::unit(105, "mm"), height = ggplot2::unit(105, "mm")) }  if (requireNamespace("cluster", quietly = TRUE)) {     # Make the row/column name annotation thicker     Heatmap(matrix_data,         # Use the "name." prefix         column_annotation_params = list(name.columns = list(height = 5)),         row_annotation_params = list(name.rows = list(width = 5))) }   # Use long form data N <- 500 data <- data.frame(     value = rnorm(N),     c = sample(letters[1:8], N, replace = TRUE),     r = sample(LETTERS[1:5], N, replace = TRUE),     p = sample(c("x", "y"), N, replace = TRUE),     q = sample(c("X", "Y", "Z"), N, replace = TRUE),     a = as.character(sample(1:5, N, replace = TRUE)),     p1 = runif(N),     p2 = runif(N) )  if (requireNamespace("cluster", quietly = TRUE)) {     Heatmap(data, rows_by = "r", columns_by = "c", values_by = "value",         rows_split_by = "p", columns_split_by = "q", show_column_names = TRUE) }  if (requireNamespace("cluster", quietly = TRUE)) {     # split into multiple heatmaps     Heatmap(data,         values_by = "value", columns_by = "c", rows_by = "r", split_by = "p",         upper_cutoff = 2, lower_cutoff = -2, legend.position = c("none", "right"),         design = "AAAAAA#BBBBBBB"     ) }  if (requireNamespace("cluster", quietly = TRUE)) {     # cell_type = "bars" (default is "tile")     Heatmap(data, values_by = "value", rows_by = "r", columns_by = "c",         cell_type = "bars") }  if (requireNamespace("cluster", quietly = TRUE)) {     p <- Heatmap(data, values_by = "value", rows_by = "r", columns_by = "c",         cell_type = "dot", dot_size = length, dot_size_name = "data points",         add_bg = TRUE, add_reticle = TRUE)     p }  if (requireNamespace("cluster", quietly = TRUE)) {     dot_size_data <- p@data     # Make it big so we can see if we get the right indexing     # for dot_size function     dot_size_data["A", "a"] <- max(dot_size_data) * 2      Heatmap(data, values_by = "value", rows_by = "r", columns_by = "c",         cell_type = "dot", dot_size_name = "data points",         dot_size = function(x, i, j) ComplexHeatmap::pindex(dot_size_data, i, j),         show_row_names = TRUE, show_column_names = TRUE,         add_bg = TRUE, add_reticle = TRUE) }  if (requireNamespace("cluster", if (requireNamespace("cluster", quietly = TRUE)) {     Heatmap(data, values_by = "value", rows_by = "r", columns_by = "c",         cell_type = "violin", add_bg = TRUE, add_reticle = TRUE) }  if (requireNamespace("cluster", quietly = TRUE)) {     Heatmap(data, values_by = "value", rows_by = "r", columns_by = "c",         cell_type = "boxplot", add_bg = TRUE, add_reticle = TRUE) }  if title: ManhattanPlot — ManhattanPlot
code: # \donttest{ set.seed(1000)  nsim <- 50000  simdata <- data.frame(   "chromosome" = sample(c(1:22,"X"), size = nsim, replace = TRUE),   "position" = sample(1:100000000, size = nsim),   "P.value" = rbeta(nsim, shape1 = 5, shape2 = 1)^7,   "cohort" = sample(c("A", "B"), size = nsim, replace = TRUE) ) simdata$chromosome <- factor(simdata$chromosome, c(1:22, "X")) options(repr.plot.width=10, repr.plot.height=5)  if (requireNamespace("ggmanh", quietly = TRUE)) { ManhattanPlot(    simdata, pval_by = "P.value", chr_by = "chromosome", pos_by = "position",    title = "Simulated P.Values", ylab = "P") }   if (requireNamespace("ggmanh", quietly = TRUE)) { # split_by ManhattanPlot(    simdata, pval_by = "P.value", chr_by = "chromosome", pos_by = "position",    title = "Simulated P.Values", ylab = "P", split_by = "cohort", ncol = 1) }   if (requireNamespace("ggmanh", quietly = TRUE)) { # Customized p-value transformation and significance threshold line colors ManhattanPlot(    simdata, pval_by = "P.value", chr_by = "chromosome", pos_by = "position",    title = "Simulated -Log2 P.Values", ylab = "-log2(P)", pval_transform = "-log2",    signif_color = c("red", "blue")) }   if (requireNamespace("ggmanh", quietly = TRUE)) { # Use a different palette and don't show significance threshold labels ManhattanPlot(    simdata, pval_by = "P.value", chr_by = "chromosome", pos_by = "position",    palette = "Set1", signif_label = FALSE) }   if (requireNamespace("ggmanh", quietly = TRUE)) { # Reverse the palette and show significance threshold labels on the right ManhattanPlot(    simdata, pval_by = "P.value", chr_by = "chromosome", pos_by = "position",    palette = "Set1", palreverse = TRUE, signif_label_pos = "right") }   if (requireNamespace("ggmanh", quietly = TRUE)) { # Use chromosomes to show a single selected chromosome ManhattanPlot(    simdata, pval_by = "P.value", chr_by = "chromosome", pos_by = "position",    title = "Simulated P.Values", chromosomes = 5) }   if (requireNamespace("ggmanh", quietly = TRUE)) { # Subset and reorder chromosomes ManhattanPlot(    simdata, pval_by = "P.value", chr_by = "chromosome", pos_by = "position",    title = "Simulated P.Values", chromosomes = c(20, 4, 6)) }   tmpdata <- data.frame(   "chromosome" = c(rep(5, 10), rep(21, 5)),   "position" = c(sample(250000:250100, 10, replace = FALSE),     sample(590000:600000, 5, replace = FALSE)),   "P.value" = c(10^-(rnorm(10, 100, 3)), 10^-rnorm(5, 9, 1)),   "cohort" = c(rep("A", 10), rep("B", 5)) )  simdata <- rbind(simdata, tmpdata) simdata$chromosome <- factor(simdata$chromosome, c(1:22, "X"))  if (requireNamespace("ggmanh", quietly = TRUE)) { # Don't rescale the plot (y-axis) ManhattanPlot(     simdata, pval_by = "P.value", chr_by = "chromosome", pos_by = "position",     title = "Simulated P.Values - Significant", rescale = FALSE) }   if (requireNamespace("ggmanh", quietly = TRUE)) { # Rescale the plot (y-axis) and put the breaking point in the middle of the y-axis ManhattanPlot(     simdata, pval_by = "P.value", chr_by = "chromosome", pos_by = "position",     title = "Simulated P.Values - Significant", rescale = TRUE, signif_rel_pos = 0.5) }   sig <- simdata$P.value < 5e-07  simdata$label <- "" simdata$label[sig] <- sprintf("Label: %i", 1:sum(sig)) simdata$label2 <- "" i <- (simdata$chromosome == 5) & (simdata$P.value < 5e-8) simdata$label2[i] <- paste("Chromosome 5 label", 1:sum(i))  if (requireNamespace("ggmanh", quietly = TRUE)) { # Label the points with labels ManhattanPlot(simdata, label_by = "label", pval_by = "P.value", chr_by = "chromosome",     pos_by = "position", title = "Simulated P.Values with labels", label_size = 4) }   if (requireNamespace("ggmanh", quietly = TRUE)) { # Label the points with labels and use a different color for the labels ManhattanPlot(simdata, label_by = "label2", pval_by = "P.value", chr_by = "chromosome",     pos_by = "position", title = "Simulated P.Values with labels",     label_size = 3, label_fg = "black") }   simdata$color <- "Not Significant" simdata$color[simdata$P.value <= 5e-8] <- "Significant"  if (requireNamespace("ggmanh", quietly = TRUE)) { # Highlight points with shapes ManhattanPlot(simdata, title = "Highlight Points with shapes",     pval_by = "P.value", chr_by = "chromosome", pos_by = "position",     highlight = "color == 'Significant'", highlight_color = NULL, highlight_shape = 6,     highlight_size = 5, pt_alpha = 0.2, pt_size = 1) }   if (requireNamespace("ggmanh", quietly = TRUE)) { # Highlight points with colors ManhattanPlot(simdata, title = "Highlight Points",     pval_by = "P.value", chr_by = "chromosome", pos_by = "position",     highlight = "color == 'Significant'", highlight_color = "black",     pt_color = "lightblue", pt_alpha = 0.2, pt_size = 0.1) }  # }

title: QQ plot — QQPlot
code: set.seed(8525) data <- data.frame(norm = rnorm(100))  QQPlot(data, val = "norm", band = TRUE)  QQPlot(data, val = "norm", band = list(     list(bandType = "ks", mapping = ggplot2::aes(fill = "KS"), alpha = 0.3),     list(bandType = "ts", mapping = ggplot2::aes(fill = "TS")),     list(bandType = "pointwise", mapping = ggplot2::aes(fill = "Normal")),     list(bandType = "boot", mapping = ggplot2::aes(fill = "Bootstrap")) ), band_alpha = 0.6)   data(airquality, package = "datasets") di <- "exp" # exponential distribution dp <- list(rate = 2) # exponential rate parameter QQPlot(airquality, val = "Ozone",     band = list(distribution = di, dparams = dp),     line = list(distribution = di, dparams = dp),     point = list(distribution = di, dparams = dp) )   de <- TRUE # enabling the detrend option QQPlot(airquality, val = "Ozone",     band = list(distribution = di, dparams = dp, detrend = de),     line = list(distribution = di, dparams = dp, detrend = de),     point = list(distribution = di, dparams = dp, detrend = de) )   QQPlot(data, val = "norm", type = "pp", band = TRUE)   dp <- list(mean = 2, sd = 2) # shifted and rescaled Normal parameters QQPlot(data, val = "norm", type = "pp",     band = list(dparams = dp),     point = list(dparams = dp))   QQPlot(data, val = "norm", type = "pp", band = TRUE,     line = list(ab = c(.2, .5)))   di <- "exp" dp <- list(rate = .022) # value is based on some empirical tests de <- TRUE QQPlot(airquality, val = "Ozone", type = "pp",    band = list(distribution = di, detrend = de, dparams = dp),    line = list(detrend = de),    point = list(distribution = di, detrend = de, dparams = dp),    ylim = c(-.5, .5) )

title: ROC curve — ROCCurve
text: data data frame. truth_by character string column name contains true class labels. (.k.. binary outcome, 1/0 TRUE/FALSE.) score_by character strings column names contains predicted scores. multiple columns provided, ROC curve plotted column. pos_label character string positive class label. NULL, labels handled plotROC package. split_by column(s) split data plot separately. split_by_sep separator multiple split_by columns. See split_by group_by Columns group data plotting plotting functions support multiple groups, concatenated one column, using group_by_sep separator group_by_sep separator multiple group_by columns. See group_by group_name character string name legend ROC curve groups. x_axis_reverse logical reverse x-axis, 1 0. percent logical display x y axis percentages. ci list arguments pass plotROC::geom_rocci() add confidence intervals. NULL, confidence intervals added. n_cuts integer specify number cutpoints ROC curve. quantiles predicted scores. cutoffs_at Vector user supplied cutoffs plot points. non-NULL, override values n_cuts plot observed cutoffs closest user-supplied ones. cutoffs_at cutoffs.labels passed plotROC::geom_roc(). numeric values, following special values allowed. values methods OptimalCutpoints::optimal.cutpoints(), literally: "CB" (cost-benefit method); "MCT" (minimizes Misclassification Cost Term); "MinValueSp" (minimum value set Specificity); "MinValueSe" (minimum value set Sensitivity); "ValueSe" (value set Sensitivity); "MinValueSpSe" (minimum value set Specificity Sensitivity); "MaxSp" (maximizes Specificity); "MaxSe" (maximizes Sensitivity); "MaxSpSe" (maximizes Sensitivity Specificity simultaneously); "MaxProdSpSe" (maximizes product Sensitivity Specificity Accuracy Area); "ROC01" (minimizes distance ROC plot point (0,1)); "SpEqualSe" (Sensitivity = Specificity); "Youden" (Youden Index); "MaxEfficiency" (maximizes Efficiency Accuracy, similar minimize Error Rate); "Minimax" (minimizes frequent error); "MaxDOR" (maximizes Diagnostic Odds Ratio); "MaxKappa" (maximizes Kappa Index); "MinValueNPV" (minimum value set Negative Predictive Value); "MinValuePPV" (minimum value set Positive Predictive Value); "ValueNPV" (value set Negative Predictive Value); "ValuePPV" (value set Positive Predictive Value); "MinValueNPVPPV" (minimum value set Predictive Values); "PROC01" (minimizes distance PROC plot point (0,1)); "NPVEqualPPV" (Negative Predictive Value = Positive Predictive Value); "MaxNPVPPV" (maximizes Positive Predictive Value Negative Predictive Value simultaneously); "MaxSumNPVPPV" (maximizes sum Predictive Values); "ObservedPrev" (closest value observed prevalence); "MeanPrev" (closest value mean diagnostic test values); "PrevalenceMatching" (value predicted prevalence practically equal observed prevalence). cutoffs_labels vector user-supplied labels cutoffs. Default TRUE. aspect.ratio numeric value specifying aspect ratio plot. legend.position character string specifying position legend. waiver(), single groups, legend "none", otherwise "right". legend.direction character string specifying direction legend. title character string specifying title plot. function can used generate title based default title. useful split_by used title needs dynamic. subtitle character string specifying subtitle plot. xlab character string specifying x-axis label. ylab character string specifying y-axis label. combine Whether combine plots one facet FALSE. title: ROC curve — ROCCurve
text: patch_work::wrap_plots object list combine FALSE. can retrieve AUC values using attr(p, "auc") combine TRUE. combine FALSE, AUC value plot can retrieved using attr(p[[]], "auc").

title: ROC curve — ROCCurve
code: set.seed(8525)  D.ex <- rbinom(200, size = 1, prob = .5) M1 <- rnorm(200, mean = D.ex, sd = .65) M2 <- rnorm(200, mean = D.ex, sd = 1.5) gender <- c("Male", "Female")[rbinom(200, 1, .49) + 1]  data <- data.frame(D = D.ex, D.str = c("Healthy", "Ill")[D.ex + 1],   gender = gender, M1 = M1, M2 = M2)  ROCCurve(data, truth_by = "D", score_by = "M1")  # will warn about the positive label ROCCurve(data, truth_by = "D.str", score_by = "M1") #> Warning: 'pos_label' is NULL, value 'Ill' from 'D.str' will be used as the positive label.  ROCCurve(data, truth_by = "D", score_by = "M1", increasing = FALSE)  # Multiple ROC curves ROCCurve(data, truth_by = "D", score_by = c("M1", "M2"), group_name = "Method")  ROCCurve(data, truth_by = "D", score_by = "M1", group_by = "gender", show_auc = "plot")  # Reverse the x-axis and display the axes as percentages ROCCurve(data, truth_by = "D", score_by = "M1", x_axis_reverse = TRUE, percent = TRUE)  # Pass additional arguments to geom_roc and make the curve black ROCCurve(data, truth_by = "D", score_by = "M1", n_cuts = 10, palcolor = "black")  # Add confidence intervals ROCCurve(data, truth_by = "D", score_by = "M1", ci = list(sig.level = .01))  # Facet by a column ROCCurve(data, truth_by = "D", score_by = "M1", facet_by = "gender")  # Show cutoffs ROCCurve(data, truth_by = "D", score_by = "M1", cutoffs_at = c(0, "ROC01", "SpEqualSe"))  # Split by a column p <- ROCCurve(data, truth_by = "D", score_by = "M1", split_by = "gender",    cutoffs_at = c(0.2, "MaxSpSe")) p  # Retrieve the AUC values attr(p, "auc") #>   PANEL COORD group       AUC gender #> 1     1     1     1 0.8779167 Female #> 2     1     1     1 0.9039616   Male # Retrieve the cutoffs attr(p, "cutoffs") #>              cutoff         x         y              label ..group specificity #> 1               0.2 0.2833333 0.9250000              0.200           0.7166667 #> 2 0.359521377967435 0.2333333 0.8000000 0.360 (by MaxSpSe)           0.7666667 #> 3               0.2 0.3265306 0.8823529              0.200           0.6734694 #> 4 0.344386035694676 0.2040816 0.8235294 0.344 (by MaxSpSe)           0.7959184 #>   sensitivity gender #> 1   0.9250000 Female #> 2   0.8000000 Female #> 3   0.8823529   Male #> 4   0.8235294   Male

"MaxDOR" (maximizes Diagnostic Odds Ratio); "MaxKappa" (maximizes Kappa Index); "MinValueNPV" (minimum value set Negative Predictive Value); "MinValuePPV" (minimum value set Positive Predictive Value); "ObservedPrev" (closest value observed prevalence); "MeanPrev" (closest value mean diagnostic test values); "PrevalenceMatching" (value predicted prevalence practically equal observed prevalence). cutoffs_labels vector user-supplied labels cutoffs. title: Ridge Plot — RidgePlot
code: set.seed(8525) data <- data.frame(    x = c(rnorm(250, -1), rnorm(250, 1)),    group = rep(LETTERS[1:5], each = 100) ) RidgePlot(data, x = "x")  # fallback to a density plot #> Picking joint bandwidth of 0.371  RidgePlot(data, x = "x", add_vline = 0, vline_color = "black") #> Picking joint bandwidth of 0.371  RidgePlot(data, x = "x", group_by = "group") #> Picking joint bandwidth of 0.378  RidgePlot(data, x = "x", group_by = "group", reverse = TRUE) #> Picking joint bandwidth of 0.378  RidgePlot(data, x = "x", group_by = "group",    add_vline = TRUE, vline_color = TRUE, alpha = 0.7) #> Picking joint bandwidth of 0.378   # wide form data_wide <- data.frame(    A = rnorm(100),    B = rnorm(100),    C = rnorm(100),    D = rnorm(100),    E = rnorm(100),    group = sample(letters[1:4], 100, replace = TRUE) ) RidgePlot(data_wide, group_by = LETTERS[1:5], in_form = "wide") #> Picking joint bandwidth of 0.337  RidgePlot(data_wide, group_by = LETTERS[1:5], in_form = "wide", facet_by = "group") #> Picking joint bandwidth of 0.429 #> Picking joint bandwidth of 0.367 #> Picking joint bandwidth of 0.416 #> Picking joint bandwidth of 0.428 #> Picking joint bandwidth of 0.429 #> Picking joint bandwidth of 0.367 #> Picking joint bandwidth of 0.416 #> Picking joint bandwidth of 0.428  RidgePlot(data_wide, group_by = LETTERS[1:5], in_form = "wide", split_by = "group",    palette = list(a = "Reds", b = "Blues", c = "Greens", d = "Purples")) #> Picking joint bandwidth of 0.429 #> Picking joint bandwidth of 0.416 #> Picking joint bandwidth of 0.367 #> Picking joint bandwidth of 0.428

title: Scatter Plot — ScatterPlot
code: set.seed(8525)  data <- data.frame(    x = rnorm(20),    y = rnorm(20),    w = abs(rnorm(20)),    t = sample(c("A", "B"), 20, replace = TRUE) ) ScatterPlot(data, x = "x", y = "y")   # highlight points ScatterPlot(data, x = "x", y = "y", highlight = 'x > 0')   # size_by is a numeric column ScatterPlot(data, x = "x", y = "y", size_by = "w")   # color_by is a numeric column ScatterPlot(data, x = "x", y = "y", color_by = "w")   # color_by is a factor/character column and set a border_color ScatterPlot(data, x = "x", y = "y", size_by = "w", color_by = "t",  border_color = "red")   # Same border_color as the fill color ScatterPlot(data, x = "x", y = "y", size_by = "w", color_by = "t",  border_color = TRUE)   # Shape doesn't have fill color ScatterPlot(data, x = "x", y = "y", size_by = "w", color_by = "t",  shape = 1, palette = "Set1")   # Change color per plot ScatterPlot(data, x = "x", y = "y", split_by = "t",             palcolor = list(A = "blue", B = "red"))

code: VennDiagramAtomic(   data,   in_form = "auto",   group_by = NULL,   group_by_sep = "_",   id_by = NULL,   label = "count",   label_fg = "black",   label_size = NULL,   label_bg = "white",   label_bg_r = 0.1,   fill_mode = "count",   fill_name = NULL,   palette = ifelse(fill_mode == "set", "Paired", "Spectral"),   palcolor = NULL,   alpha = 1,   theme = "theme_this",   theme_args = list(),   title = NULL,   subtitle = NULL,   legend.position = "right",   legend.direction = "vertical",   ... )

title: Atomic Venn diagram — VennDiagramAtomic
text: data data frame. in_form character string indicating datatype input data. Possible values "long", "wide", "list", "venn" NULL. "long" indicates data long format. "wide" indicates data wide format. "list" indicates data list. "venn" indicates data VennPlotData object. "auto" indicates function detect datatype input data. long format data look like: wide format data look like: list format data look like: group_by character string specifying column name data frame group data. in_form "wide", columns groups. group_by_sep separator multiple group_by columns. See group_by id_by character string specifying column name data frame identify instances. Required group_by single column data data frame. label character string specifying label show Venn diagram. Possible values "count", "percent", "", "none" function. "count" indicates count intersection. "percent" indicates percentage intersection. "" indicates count percentage intersection. "none" indicates label. function, takes data frame input returns character vector label. data frame columns "id", "X", "Y", "name", "item" "count". label_fg character string specifying color label text. label_size numeric value specifying size label text. label_bg character string specifying background color label. label_bg_r numeric value specifying radius background label. fill_mode character string specifying fill mode Venn diagram. Possible values "count", "set", "count_rev". "count" indicates fill color based count intersection. "set" indicates fill color based set intersection. "count_rev" indicates fill color based count intersection reverse order. palette continuous "count" "count_rev". palette discrete "set". fill_name character string name legend colorbar. palette character string specifying palette use. named list vector can used specify palettes different split_by values. palcolor character string specifying color use palette. named list can used specify colors different split_by values. values missing, values palette used (palcolor NULL values). alpha numeric value specifying transparency plot. theme character string theme class (.e. ggplot2::theme_classic) specifying theme use. Default "theme_this". theme_args list arguments pass theme function. title character string specifying title plot. function can used generate title based default title. useful split_by used title needs dynamic. subtitle character string specifying subtitle plot. legend.position character string specifying position legend. waiver(), single groups, legend "none", otherwise "right". legend.direction character string specifying direction legend. ... Additional arguments.
code: group_by id_by A        a1 A        a2 B        a1 B        a3 ... A    B TRUE TRUE TRUE FALSE FALSE TRUE ... list(A = c("a1", "a2"), B = c("a1", "a3"))

title: Bar Plot — BarPlot
code: # \donttest{ data <- data.frame(     x = c("A", "B", "C", "D", "E", "F", "G", "H"),     y = c(10, 8, 16, 4, 6, 12, 14, 2),     group = c("G1", "G1", "G2", "G2", "G3", "G3", "G4", "G4"),     facet = c("F1", "F2", "F3", "F4", "F1", "F2", "F3", "F4") )  BarPlot(data, x = "x", y = "y")  BarPlot(data, x = "x", y = "y", fill_by_x_if_no_group = FALSE)  BarPlot(data, x = "x", y = "y", label = TRUE)  BarPlot(data, x = "x", y = "y", label = "facet", label_nudge = 0)  BarPlot(data, x = "group", y = "y", group_by = "x")  BarPlot(data,     x = "group", y = "y", group_by = "x",     position = "dodge", add_bg = TRUE )  BarPlot(data,     x = "x", y = "y", split_by = "group",     facet_by = "facet", position = "dodge", facet_ncol = 1 )  BarPlot(data,     x = "x", y = "y", split_by = "group", facet_by = "facet",     position = "dodge", facet_ncol = 1, guides = 'collect' )  BarPlot(data,     x = "x", y = "y", split_by = "group",     palette = list(G1 = "Reds", G2 = "Blues", G3 = "Greens", G4 = "Purp"),     facet_by = "facet", position = "dodge", facet_ncol = 1 )  BarPlot(data,     x = "group", y = "y", group_by = "x",     position = "dodge", add_bg = TRUE, bg_palette = "Spectral" )  # use the count BarPlot(data, x = "group", ylab = "count")  # flip the plot BarPlot(data, x = "group", flip = TRUE, ylab = "count")  # } data <- data.frame(     word = c("apple", "banana", "cherry", "date", "elderberry",              "It is a very long term with a lot of words"),     count = c(-10, 20, -30, 40, 50, 34),     score = c(1, 2, 3, 4, 5, 3.2),     group = c("A", "A", "B", "B", "C", "C") ) SplitBarPlot(data, x = "count", y = "word", alpha_by = "score")  SplitBarPlot(data, x = "count", y = "word", alpha_by = "score",              max_charwidth = 30, lineheight = 1.1)  SplitBarPlot(data, x = "count", y = "word", fill_by = "group")  SplitBarPlot(data, x = "count", y = "word", facet_by = "group",              fill_name = "Direction")  SplitBarPlot(data, x = "count", y = "word", alpha_by = "score", split_by="group",              palette = c(A = "Reds", B = "Blues", C = "Greens"))

Either "long" "wide". split_by column(s) split data plot separately. split_by_sep separator multiple split_by columns. See split_by symnum_args list arguments pass function symnum symbolic number coding p-values. example, symnum_args <- list(cutpoints = c(0, 0.0001, 0.001, 0.01, 0.05, Inf), symbols = c("****", "***", "**", "*", "ns")). words, use following convention symbols indicating statistical significance: ns: p > 0.05 *: p <= 0.05 **: p <= 0.01 ***: p <= 0.001 ****: p <= 0.0001 sort_x character string specify sorting x-axis, chosen "none", "mean_asc", "mean_desc", "mean", "median_asc", "median_desc", "median". none means sorting (-). mean_asc sorts x-axis ascending mean y-values. mean_desc sorts x-axis descending mean y-values. mean alias mean_asc. median_asc sorts x-axis ascending median y-values. median_desc sorts x-axis descending median y-values. median alias median_asc. flip logical value flip plot. keep_empty logical value indicating whether keep empty groups. FALSE, empty groups removed. group_by Columns group data plotting plotting functions support multiple groups, concatenated one column, using group_by_sep separator group_by_sep separator multiple group_by columns. See group_by group_name character string name legend dodge. paired_by character string column name identifying paired observations paired tests. x_text_angle numeric value specifying angle x-axis text. step_increase numeric value specify step increase fraction total height every additional comparison significance labels. fill_mode character string specify fill mode. Either "dodge", "x", "mean", "median". fill_reverse logical value reverse fill colors gradient fill (mean/median). theme character string theme class (.e. ggplot2::theme_classic) specifying theme use. Default "theme_this". theme_args list arguments pass theme function. palette character string specifying palette use. named list vector can used specify palettes different split_by values. palcolor character string specifying color use palette. named list can used specify colors different split_by values. values missing, values palette used (palcolor NULL values). alpha numeric value specifying transparency plot. aspect.ratio numeric value specifying aspect ratio plot. legend.position character string specifying position legend. waiver(), single groups, legend "none", otherwise "right". legend.direction character string specifying direction legend. add_point logical value add (jitter) points plot. pt_color character string specify color points. pt_size numeric value specify size points. pt_alpha numeric value specify transparency points. jitter_width numeric value specify width jitter. TRUE, highlight points. highlight_color character string specify color highlighted points. highlight_size numeric value specify size highlighted points. highlight_alpha numeric value specify transparency highlighted points. comparisons logical value list vectors perform pairwise comparisons. TRUE, perform pairwise comparisons pairs. ref_group character string specify reference group comparisons. pairwise_method character string specify pairwise comparison method. multiplegroup_comparisons logical value perform multiple group comparisons. multiple_method character string specify multiple group comparison method. sig_label character string specify label significance test. multiple group comparisons (multiplegroup_comparisons = TRUE), must either "p.format" "p.signif". pairwise comparisons, can : column containing label (e.g.: label = "p" label = "p.adj"), p p-value. possible values "p.signif", "p.adj.signif", "p.format", "p.adj.format". expression can formatted glue() package. example, specifying label = "Wilcoxon, p = {p}", expression {p} replaced value. combination plotmath expressions glue expressions. may want statistical parameter italic; example: label = "Wilcoxon, p= {p}" See https://rpkgs.datanovia.com/ggpubr/reference/geom_pwc.html details. sig_labelsize numeric value specify size significance test label. hide_ns logical value hide non-significant comparisons. facet_by character string specifying column name data frame facet plot. title: Box / Violin Plot — BoxPlot

title: Box / Violin Plot — BoxPlot
code: # \donttest{ set.seed(8525) data <- data.frame(     x = rep(LETTERS[1:8], each = 40),     y = c(rnorm(160), rnorm(160, mean = 1)),     group1 = sample(c("g1", "g2"), 320, replace = TRUE),     group2 = sample(c("h1", "h2", "h3", "h4"), 320, replace = TRUE) )  BoxPlot(data, x = "x", y = "y")  BoxPlot(data,     x = "x", y = "y",     stack = TRUE, flip = TRUE, facet_by = "group1",     add_bg = TRUE, bg_palette = "Paired" )  BoxPlot(data,     x = "x", y = "y",     stack = TRUE, flip = TRUE, split_by = "group1",     add_bg = TRUE, bg_palette = "Paired",     palcolor = list(g1 = c("red", "blue"), g2 = c("blue", "red")) )   # wide form data data_wide <- data.frame(     A = rnorm(100),     B = rnorm(100),     C = rnorm(100) ) BoxPlot(data_wide, x = c("A", "B", "C"), in_form = "wide")   paired_data <- data.frame(     subject = rep(paste0("s", 1:10), each = 2),     visit = rep(c("pre", "post"), times = 10),     value = rnorm(20) ) # paired plot with connected lines and paired test BoxPlot(     paired_data,     x = "visit", y = "value", comparisons = TRUE,     paired_by = "subject", add_point = TRUE )  paired_group_data <- data.frame(     subject = rep(paste0("s", 1:6), each = 2),     x = rep(c("A", "B"), each = 6),     group = rep(c("before", "after"), times = 6),     value = rnorm(12) ) BoxPlot(     paired_group_data,     x = "x", y = "value",     paired_by = "subject", group_by = "group",     comparisons = TRUE, pt_size = 3, pt_color = "red" ) #> Warning: Forcing 'add_point' = TRUE when 'paired_by' is provided.  # } # \donttest{ ViolinPlot(data, x = "x", y = "y")  ViolinPlot(data, x = "x", y = "y", add_box = TRUE)  ViolinPlot(data, x = "x", y = "y", add_point = TRUE)  ViolinPlot(data, x = "x", y = "y", add_trend = TRUE)  ViolinPlot(data, x = "x", y = "y", add_stat = mean)  ViolinPlot(data, x = "x", y = "y", add_bg = TRUE)  ViolinPlot(data, x = "x", y = "y", add_line = 0)  ViolinPlot(data, x = "x", y = "y", group_by = "group1")  ViolinPlot(data,     x = "x", y = "y", group_by = "group1",     facet_by = "group2", add_box = TRUE ) #> Warning: Groups with fewer than two datapoints have been dropped. #> ℹ Set `drop = FALSE` to consider such groups for position adjustment purposes. #> Warning: Groups with fewer than two datapoints have been dropped. #> ℹ Set `drop = FALSE` to consider such groups for position adjustment purposes. #> Warning: Groups with fewer than two datapoints have been dropped. #> ℹ Set `drop = FALSE` to consider such groups for position adjustment purposes. #> Warning: Groups with fewer than two datapoints have been dropped. #> ℹ Set `drop = FALSE` to consider such groups for position adjustment purposes.  ViolinPlot(data, x = "x", y = "y", add_point = TRUE, highlight = 'group1 == "g1"',     alpha = 0.8, highlight_size = 1.5, pt_size = 1, add_box = TRUE)  ViolinPlot(data,     x = "x", y = "y", group_by = "group1",     comparisons = TRUE, sig_label = "p = {p}" )  ViolinPlot(data,     x = "x", y = "y", sig_label = "p.format", hide_ns = TRUE,     facet_by = "group2", comparisons = list(c("D", "E")) )  ViolinPlot(data,     x = "x", y = "y", fill_mode = "mean",     facet_by = "group2", palette = "Blues", multiplegroup_comparisons = TRUE ) #> Warning: The following aesthetics were dropped during statistical transformation: fill. #> ℹ This can happen when ggplot fails to infer the correct grouping structure in #>   the data. #> ℹ Did you forget to specify a `group` aesthetic or to convert a numerical #>   variable into a factor? #> Warning: The following aesthetics were dropped during statistical transformation: fill. #> ℹ This can happen when ggplot fails to infer the correct grouping structure in #>   the data. #> ℹ Did you forget to specify a `group` aesthetic or to convert a numerical #>   variable into a factor? #> Warning: The following aesthetics were dropped during statistical transformation: fill. #> ℹ This can happen when ggplot fails to infer the correct grouping structure in #>   the data. #> ℹ Did you forget to specify a `group` aesthetic or to convert a numerical #>   variable into a factor?  ViolinPlot(data,     x = "x", y = "y", fill_mode = "mean",     split_by = "group1", palette = c(g1 = "Blues", g2 = "Reds") )  ViolinPlot(data,     x = "x", y = "y", stack = TRUE,     facet_by = "group2", add_box = TRUE, add_bg = TRUE,     bg_palette = "Paired" )  # }

title: Density Plot / Histogram — DensityPlot
code: set.seed(8525) data <- data.frame(     x = c(rnorm(500, -1), rnorm(500, 1)),     group = rep(c("A", "B"), each = 500),     facet = sample(c("F1", "F2"), 1000, replace = TRUE) )  DensityPlot(data, x = "x")  DensityPlot(data, x = "x", group_by = "group", facet_by = "facet")  DensityPlot(data, x = "x", split_by = "facet", add_bars = TRUE)  DensityPlot(data, x = "x", split_by = "facet", add_bars = TRUE,     palette = c(F1 = "Set1", F2 = "Set2"))  set.seed(8525) data <- data.frame(     x = sample(setdiff(1:100, c(30:36, 50:55, 70:77)), 1000, replace = TRUE),     group = factor(rep(c("A", "B"), each = 500), levels = c("A", "B")),     facet = sample(c("F1", "F2"), 1000, replace = TRUE) )  Histogram(data, x = "x") #> Using `bins = 30`. Pick better value with `binwidth`.  Histogram(data, x = "x", group_by = "group") #> Using `bins = 30`. Pick better value with `binwidth`.  Histogram(data, x = "x", split_by = "facet", add_bars = TRUE) #> Using `bins = 30`. Pick better value with `binwidth`. #> Using `bins = 30`. Pick better value with `binwidth`.  Histogram(data, x = "x", group_by = "group", add_trend = TRUE) #> Using `bins = 30`. Pick better value with `binwidth`.  Histogram(data, x = "x", group_by = "group", add_trend = TRUE, trend_skip_zero = TRUE) #> Using `bins = 30`. Pick better value with `binwidth`.  Histogram(data, x = "x", group_by = "group", split_by = "facet",  use_trend = TRUE, trend_pt_size = 3) #> Using `bins = 30`. Pick better value with `binwidth`. #> Using `bins = 30`. Pick better value with `binwidth`.  Histogram(data, x = "x", group_by = "group", split_by = "facet",  palette = c(F1 = "Paired", F2 = "Spectral")) #> Using `bins = 30`. Pick better value with `binwidth`. #> Using `bins = 30`. Pick better value with `binwidth`.

text: data data frame. dims character vector column names plot x y axes numeric vector column indices. group_by Columns group data plotting plotting functions support multiple groups, concatenated one column, using group_by_sep separator group_by_sep separator multiple group_by columns. Default 1. velocity_min_mass numeric value minimum mass velocity. Default 1. velocity_cutoff_perc numeric value velocity cutoff percentage. Default 5. streamline_minl optional numeric value specifying minimum length velocity streamlines. Default 1. streamline_res optional numeric value specifying resolution velocity streamlines. Default 1. streamline_n optional numeric value specifying number velocity streamlines draw. Default 15. streamline_width numeric vector length 2 specifying width velocity streamlines. Default c(0, 0.8). streamline_alpha numeric value specifying transparency velocity streamlines. Default 1 (fully opaque). streamline_color character string specifying color velocity streamlines. streamline_palette character string specifying color palette use velocity streamlines. Default "white". streamline_bg_stroke numeric value specifying background stroke width velocity streamlines. Default 0.5. facet_by character string specifying column name data frame facet plot. Otherwise, data split split_by generate multiple plots combine one using patchwork::wrap_plots facet_scales Whether scale axes facets. Default "fixed" options "free", "free_x", "free_y". Default NULL. palette character string specifying palette use. named list vector can used specify palettes different split_by values. palcolor character string specifying color use palette. named list can used specify colors different split_by values. values missing, values palette used (palcolor NULL values). seed random seed use. Default 8525. combine Whether combine plots one facet FALSE. Default TRUE. nrow numeric value specifying number rows facet. ncol numeric value specifying number columns facet. byrow logical value indicating whether fill plots row. axes string specifying axes treated. Passed patchwork::wrap_plots(). relevant split_by used combine TRUE. Options : 'keep' retain axes individual plots. 'collect' remove duplicated axes placed run rows columns layout. 'collect_x' 'collect_y' remove duplicated x-axes columns duplicated y-axes rows respectively. axis_titles string specifying axis titltes treated. 'collect' remove duplicated titles one direction merge titles opposite direction. 'collect_x' 'collect_y' control x-axis titles y-axis titles respectively. guides string specifying guides treated layout. Passed patchwork::wrap_plots(). relevant split_by used combine TRUE. Options : 'collect' collect guides given nesting level, removing duplicates. 'keep' stop collection level let guides placed alongside plot. 'auto' allow guides collected upper level tries, place alongside plot . design Specification location areas layout, passed patchwork::wrap_plots(). relevant split_by used combine TRUE. specified, nrow, ncol, byrow ignored. See patchwork::wrap_plots() details. ... Additional arguments. features character vector column names plot features. lower_quantile, upper_quantile, lower_cutoff, upper_cutoff Vector minimum maximum cutoff values quantile values feature. bg_cutoff numeric value used cutoff set feature values NA. Default NULL. color_name character string color legend name. Default "".

code: # \donttest{ mtcars <- datasets::mtcars mtcars$carb <- factor(mtcars$carb) mtcars$gear <- factor(mtcars$gear) DotPlot(mtcars, x = "carb", y = "gear", size_by = "wt",         fill_by = "mpg", fill_cutoff = 18)  DotPlot(mtcars, x = "carb", y = "gear", size_by = "wt",         fill_by = "mpg", fill_cutoff = 18, add_bg = TRUE)  DotPlot(mtcars, x = "carb", y = "gear", size_by = "wt",         fill_by = "mpg", fill_cutoff = 18, add_bg = TRUE,         bg_direction = "h")  DotPlot(mtcars, x = "carb", y = "gear", size_by = "wt",         fill_by = "mpg", fill_cutoff = 18, facet_by = "cyl")  DotPlot(mtcars, x = "carb", y = "gear", size_by = "wt",         fill_by = "mpg", fill_cutoff = 18, facet_by = "cyl",         facet_scales = "free_x")  DotPlot(mtcars, x = "carb", y = "gear", size_by = "wt",         fill_by = "mpg", fill_cutoff = 18, split_by = "cyl")  DotPlot(mtcars, x = "carb", y = "gear", size_by = "wt",         fill_by = "mpg", fill_cutoff = 18, split_by = "cyl",         palette = list("4" = "Set1", "6" = "Paired", "8" = "Reds"))  # works as a scatter plot DotPlot(mtcars, x = "qsec", y = "drat", size_by = "wt",         fill_by = "mpg", fill_cutoff = 18, fill_cutoff_name = "Small mpgs")  # } LollipopPlot(mtcars, x = "qsec", y = "drat", size_by = "wt",              fill_by = "mpg")  LollipopPlot(mtcars, x = "qsec", y = "drat", size_by = "wt",              fill_by = "mpg", fill_cutoff = 18, facet_by = "cyl",              facet_scales = "free_y")  LollipopPlot(mtcars, x = "qsec", y = "drat", size_by = "wt",              split_by = "vs", palette = list("0" = "Reds", "1" = "Blues"))

title: Enrichment Map/Network — EnrichMap
text: EnrichMap function plot enrichment map. EnrichNetwork function plot enrichment network.

title: Enrichment Map/Network — EnrichMap
code: EnrichMap(   data,   in_form = c("auto", "clusterProfiler", "clusterprofiler", "enrichr"),   split_by = NULL,   split_by_sep = "_",   top_term = 10,   metric = "p.adjust",   layout = "fr",   minchar = 2,   cluster = "fast_greedy",   show_keyword = FALSE,   nlabel = 4,   character_width = 50,   mark = "ellipse",   label = c("term", "feature"),   labelsize = 5,   expand = c(0.4, 0.4),   theme = "theme_this",   theme_args = list(),   palette = "Paired",   palcolor = NULL,   alpha = 1,   aspect.ratio = 1,   legend.position = "right",   legend.direction = "vertical",   title = NULL,   subtitle = NULL,   xlab = NULL,   ylab = NULL,   seed = 8525,   combine = TRUE,   nrow = NULL,   ncol = NULL,   byrow = TRUE,   axes = NULL,   axis_titles = axes,   guides = NULL,   design = NULL,   ... )  EnrichNetwork(   data,   in_form = c("auto", "clusterProfiler", "clusterprofiler", "enrichr"),   split_by = NULL,   split_by_sep = "_",   top_term = 10,   metric = "p.adjust",   character_width = 50,   layout = "fr",   layoutadjust = TRUE,   adjscale = 60,   adjiter = 100,   blendmode = "blend",   labelsize = 5,   theme = "theme_this",   theme_args = list(),   palette = "Paired",   palcolor = NULL,   alpha = 1,   aspect.ratio = 1,   legend.position = "right",   legend.direction = "vertical",   title = NULL,   subtitle = NULL,   xlab = NULL,   ylab = NULL,   seed = 8525,   combine = TRUE,   nrow = NULL,   ncol = NULL,   byrow = TRUE,   axes = NULL,   axis_titles = axes,   guides = NULL,   design = NULL,   ... )

title: Enrichment Map/Network — EnrichMap
text: data data frame containing data plotted. format clusterProfiler enrichment result, includes columns: ID, Description, GeneRatio, BgRatio, pvalue, p.adjust, qvalue, geneID Count. ID, qvalue Count columns optional. Description description term. GeneRatio number genes term divided total number genes input list. BgRatio number genes term divided total number genes background list (terms). Count column, given, first number GeneRatio. enrichment results multiple databases, can combine one data frame add column (e.g. Database) indicate database. can plot single plot using split_by argument (e.g. split_by = "Database"). in_form character string specifying input format. Either "auto", "clusterProfiler", "clusterprofiler" "enrichr". default "auto", try infer input format. split_by column(s) split data plot separately. split_by_sep separator multiple split_by columns. See split_by top_term integer specifying number top terms show. metric character string specifying metric use size nodes. also used order terms selected top terms. Either "pvalue" "p.adjust". default "p.adjust". layout character string specifying layout graph. Either "circle", "tree", "grid" layout functions igraph. minchar integer specifying minimum number characters show keyword. cluster character string specifying clustering method. Either "fast_greedy", "walktrap", "edge_betweenness", "infomap" clustering functions igraph. show_keyword logical value specifying whether show keyword instead Description/Term plot. nlabel integer specifying number labels show cluster. character_width width characters used wrap keyword. mark character string specifying mark use nodes. Either "ellipse", "rect", "circle", "text" mark functions ggforce. label character string specifying label show legend. Either "term" "feature". default "term". labelsize numeric value specifying size label. expand values expand x y axes. like CSS padding. single value provided, used axes sides. two values provided, first value used top/bottom side second value used left/right side. three values provided, first value used top side, second value used left/right side, third value used bottom side. four values provided, values used top, right, bottom, left sides, respectively. can also use named vector specify values side. axis discrete, values applied 'add' 'expansion' function. axis continuous, values applied 'mult' 'expansion' function. See also https://ggplot2.tidyverse.org/reference/expansion.html theme character string theme class (.e. ggplot2::theme_classic) specifying theme use. Default "theme_this". theme_args list arguments pass theme function. palette character string specifying palette use. named list vector can used specify palettes different split_by values. palcolor character string specifying color use palette. named list can used specify colors different split_by values. values missing, values palette used (palcolor NULL values). alpha numeric value specifying transparency plot. aspect.ratio numeric value specifying aspect ratio plot. legend.position character string specifying position legend. waiver(), single groups, legend "none", otherwise "right". legend.direction character string specifying direction legend. title character string specifying title plot. function can used generate title based default title. useful split_by used title needs dynamic. subtitle character string specifying subtitle plot. xlab character string specifying x-axis label. ylab character string specifying y-axis label. seed random seed use. Default 8525. combine Whether combine plots one facet FALSE. Default TRUE. nrow numeric value specifying number rows facet. ncol numeric value specifying number columns facet. byrow logical value indicating whether fill plots row. axes string specifying axes treated. Passed patchwork::wrap_plots(). relevant split_by used combine TRUE. Options : 'keep' retain axes individual plots. 'collect' remove duplicated axes placed run rows columns layout. 'collect_x' 'collect_y' remove duplicated x-axes columns duplicated y-axes rows respectively. axis_titles string specifying axis titltes treated. Passed patchwork::wrap_plots(). relevant split_by used combine TRUE. Options : 'keep' retain axis titles individual plots. 'collect' remove duplicated titles one direction merge titles opposite direction. 'collect_x' 'collect_y' control x-axis titles y-axis titles respectively. guides string specifying guides treated layout. Passed patchwork::wrap_plots(). relevant split_by used combine TRUE. Options : 'collect' collect guides given nesting level, removing duplicates. 'keep' stop collection level let guides placed alongside plot. 'auto' allow guides collected upper level tries, place alongside plot . design Specification location areas layout, passed patchwork::wrap_plots(). relevant split_by used combine TRUE. specified, nrow, ncol, byrow ignored. See patchwork::wrap_plots() details. ... Additional arguments. layoutadjust logical value specifying whether adjust layout network. adjscale numeric value specifying scale adjustment. adjiter numeric value specifying number iterations adjustment. blendmode character string specifying blend mode colors. Either "blend", "average", "multiply" "screen".

title: GSEA plots — GSEASummaryPlot
text: data data frame GSEA results example, DOSE::gseDO(). Required columns ID, Description, NES, p.adjust, pvalue. ID column used match gene sets. in_form format input data fgsea: input data fgsea package. dose: input data DOSE package. auto: Automatically detect format input data. "leadingEdge" input data, treated "fgsea"; otherwise, "core_enrichment" input data, treated "dose". gene_ranks numeric vector gene ranks genes names gene ranks used plot gene sets. gene_ranks character vector starting @, gene ranks taken attribute data. gene_sets list gene sets, typically record GMT file names list match ID column data. gene_sets character vector starting @, gene sets taken attribute data. GSEA plots plotted gene set. , number plots number gene sets. want plot subset gene sets, can subset gene_sets passing function. top_term integer select top terms metric metric use significance terms Typically column name p values adjusted p values. also used select top terms. cutoff cutoff significance terms terms filtered cutoff; filtered top_term ranked metric. cutoff used show significance terms plot. terms significant, color grey. character_width width characters y-axis line_plot_size size line plots metric_name name metric show color bar nonsig_name name legend nonsignificant terms linewidth width lines line plots line_by method calculate line plots. prerank: Use gene ranks heights plot line plots. running_score: Use running score plot line plots. title character string specifying title plot. function can used generate title based default title. useful split_by used title needs dynamic. subtitle character string specifying subtitle plot. xlab character string specifying x-axis label. ylab character string specifying y-axis label. alpha numeric value specifying transparency plot. aspect.ratio numeric value specifying aspect ratio plot. legend.position character string specifying position legend. waiver(), single groups, legend "none", otherwise "right". legend.direction character string specifying direction legend. theme character string theme class (.e. ggplot2::theme_classic) specifying theme use. Default "theme_this". theme_args list arguments pass theme function. palette character string specifying palette use. named list vector can used specify palettes different split_by values. palcolor character string specifying color use palette. named list can used specify colors different split_by values. values missing, values palette used (palcolor NULL values). seed random seed use. Default 8525. ... Additional arguments. gs names gene sets plot NULL, gene sets gene_sets plotted. sample_coregenes logical value sample core genes core_enrichment; FALSE, first n_coregenes used line_width width line running score plot line_alpha alpha line running score plot line_color color line running score plot n_coregenes number core genes label genes_label genes label. set, n_coregenes ignored label_fg color label text label_bg background color label label_bg_r radius background color label label_size size label text combine Whether combine plots one facet FALSE. Default TRUE. nrow numeric value specifying number rows facet. ncol numeric value specifying number columns facet. byrow logical value indicating whether fill plots row. axes string specifying axes treated. Passed patchwork::wrap_plots(). relevant split_by used combine TRUE. Options : 'keep' retain axes individual plots. 'collect' remove duplicated axes placed run rows columns layout. 'collect_x' 'collect_y' remove duplicated x-axes columns duplicated y-axes rows respectively. axis_titles string specifying axis titltes treated. Passed patchwork::wrap_plots(). relevant split_by used combine TRUE. Options : 'keep' retain axis titles individual plots. 'collect' remove duplicated titles one direction merge titles opposite direction. 'collect_x' 'collect_y' control x-axis titles y-axis titles respectively. guides string specifying guides treated layout. Passed patchwork::wrap_plots(). relevant split_by used combine TRUE. Options : 'collect' collect guides given nesting level, removing duplicates. 'keep' stop collection level let guides placed alongside plot. 'auto' allow guides collected upper level tries, place alongside plot . design Specification location areas layout, passed patchwork::wrap_plots(). relevant split_by used combine TRUE. specified, nrow, ncol, byrow ignored. See patchwork::wrap_plots() details.

title: An example of GSEA result from fgsea package — gsea_example
code: # \dontrun{ if (interactive()) {  set.seed(1234)  data(geneList, package="DOSE")  gsea_example <- DOSE::gseDO(geneList)  gene_ranks <- gsea_example@geneList  gene_sets <- gsea_example@geneSets  gsea_example_pos <- gsea_example[gsea_example$p.adjust < 0.05 & gsea_example$NES > 0, ]  gsea_example_neg <- gsea_example[gsea_example$p.adjust < 0.05 & gsea_example$NES < 0, ]  gsea_example <- rbind(      gsea_example_pos[sample(1:nrow(gsea_example_pos), 5), ],      gsea_example_pos[sample(1:nrow(gsea_example_pos), 5), ]  )   attr(gsea_example, "gene_ranks") <- gene_ranks  attr(gsea_example, "gene_sets") <- gene_sets[gsea_example$ID] } # }
